title: New AI classifier for indicating AI-written text

last_post.content:
So OpenAI just released a detector of AI-generated text, I assume because of concerns in education / homework.

https://openai.com/blog/new-ai-classifier-for-indicating-ai-written-text/

Maybe this is good?

No, it's very bad.

They claim 26% true positives, 9% false positives. Assume 10% of submitted homework is chatgpt generated, you get the classic counterintuitive outcome of poor predictive power: if a homework is flagged, there's a 3:1 chance it's *human* generated.

This is going to cause a lot of harm. It should be immediately recalled.

title: 4chan users embrace AI voice clone tool to generate celebrity hatespeech

last_post.content:
It's 2023. "Gosh, we didn't realize how people would misuse this" just isn't believable anymore.

Bare minimum, with any new tech:
1) How would a stalker use this?
2) What will 4chan do with this?

And don't release, not even as alpha or beta, before mitigating those risks.

https://www.theverge.com/2023/1/31/23579289/ai-voice-clone-deepfake-abuse-4chan-elevenlabs

#AIethics #ethNLP
So when Twitter shuts down its API access in a week, migration tools like the great https://movetodon.org from @Tibor will stop working. If you want to migrate your followers do it now!

Time for an #introduction post from me I think

Hi, I'm Simon! I'm a full-time open source developer based in Half Moon Bay, California (half an hour south of San Francisco), mostly working on https://datasette.io and the 100+ (seriously) tools and plugins around it.

The theme of my work is helping people explore, analyze and publish their data.

You can learn lots more about me in this post I wrote celebrating my blog's 20th birthday https://simonwillison.net/2022/Jun/12/twenty-years/

title: Global North and Global South - Wikipedia

last_post.content:
We're organizing a free Bayesian Data Analysis course targeted for Global south (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_North_and_Global_South) and other underrepresented groups. This is currently the third rendition of the BDA GSU course. See more information and the link to the registration form at https://avehtari.github.io/BDA_course_Aalto/gsu2023.html

The course is based on BDA3 book and BDA course at
Aalto. All course material is freely available.

title: arXiv announces new policy on ChatGPT and similar tools – arXiv.org blog

last_post.content:
ArXiv issues new policy on large language models as authors: https://blog.arxiv.org/2023/01/31/arxiv-announces-new-policy-on-chatgpt-and-similar-tools/

TL;DR: no, language models cannot take responsibility for the content of a paper and therefore cannot be listed as an author

title: Create a release checklist in a GitHub issue — use_release_issue

last_post.content:
today's #rstats function you might not know about:

usethis::use_release_issue() creates a GH issue with a common-sense checklist of steps to follow while releasing a package

as someone prone to making mistakes during fiddly, repetitive processes like releases, following these checklists has saved me so much time & angst about breaking the CRAN release

https://usethis.r-lib.org/reference/use_release_issue.html

title: New OSF Metadata to Support Data Sharing Policy Compliance

last_post.content:
Major enhancement to OSF metadata released today for projects and files. This release has been a long time coming to advance FAIR data on OSF, and it sets the stage for big future releases improving reporting and search and discovery.

Read more about it: https://www.cos.io/blog/new-osf-metadata-to-support-data-sharing-policy-compliance

title: GitHub - kdeldycke/awesome-falsehood: 😱 Falsehoods Programmers Believe in

last_post.content:
“This is a recurring form of techno-hubris: the idea that baseline concepts like "family" have crisp definitions and that any exceptions are outliers that would never swallow the rule. It's such a common misstep that there's a whole genre called "Falsehoods Programmers Believe About ______": https://github.com/kdeldycke/awesome-falsehood In that list: names, time, currency, birthdays, timezones, email addresses, national borders, nations, biometrics, gender, language, alphabets, phone numbers, addresses, systems of measurement, and, of course, families.” —@pluralistic via https://pluralistic.net/2023/02/02/nonbinary-families/

I didn’t know this genre was so packed.

title: Harvard Misinformation Expert Joan Donovan Forced to Leave by Kennedy School Dean, Sources Say | News | The Harvard Crimson

last_post.content:
Harvard is shutting down prominent misinformation expert Joan Donovan's project, forcing her out of her research director position. The project has a team >25 people—led by Donovan since 2019.

Donovan was told that her prominence led to the Dean's decision to remove her. The Center Director said in an email that the decision "was 'solely driven' by [the] policy of only allowing full professors to lead research projects."

via https://www.thecrimson.com/article/2023/2/2/donovan-forced-leave-hks/

Once upon a time I made a scoreboard for Canabalt with the Twitter API. You can still see it at http://capndesign.com/canabalt/. For over year, I worked at ThinkUp which only existed because Twitter and other social sites had an API.

I’ll miss all the fun toys people built because the API was free. Shoutout to everyone who worked hard to keep it accessible and I hope we build even cooler shit on Mastodon.

title: Ron DeSantis has his own book-banning troops: the "woke busters"

last_post.content: Morning! Florida Republicans are in gaslighting mode, denying the book-banning. In reality, at least one county already is forming a volunteer police force to round up books they deem "woke." One book they hate? Michelle Obama's memoir. https://www.salon.com/2023/02/03/call-the-woke-busters-ron-desantis-sends-volunteer-army-to-snatch-books-from-students-hands/

I'm here for downward-pointing bars for numbers that represent something bad or negative. It's so much more logical than showing them pointing up, and more down = more bad is so much more immediate.
